awd_abstract_narration:
This is a project on algebraic geometry, which is one of the oldest disciplines in mathematics. It studies geometric objects called varieties that are defined by algebraic equations. Algebraic geometry has important connections to mathematical physics and coding theory. The intellectual impacts of the proposal are on improving our understanding on the relations between the geometry of algebraic curves and higher dimensional varieties to the set of relations among the equations defining the varieties. These relations are called the syzygies of the varieties. The PI will investigate the properties of the syzygies of algebraic curves and higher dimensional varieties. The PI also plans to study the irrationality of an algebraic variety, a measure of the complexity of the variety. This project has extensive educational and training components.

The PI and his collaborator Lazarsfeld will study syzygies by of the curves using the geometric properties of the subvarieties of the Hilbert schemes of points on the curve. They will investigate the asymptotic behavior of syzygies of an algebraic varieties and their relations to the intrinsic geometry of the variety. The proposed program would extend the classical results previously only known in the case of algebraic curves to higher dimensional varieties. Another part of this project is the study of the irrationality of an algebraic variety with emphasis on the case when the variety is a very general polarized K3 surface. Together with Xudong Zheng (Johns Hopkins University), the PI will study the Hilbert schemes of points for singular surfaces; in particular, the relations between the singularities of the surfaces and the geometry of Hilbert schemes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This is a project on algebraic geometry. Algebraic geometry is one of the oldest branches of mathematics. It studies properties of algebraic varieties, which are geometric objects defined by algebraic equations.  Algebraic geometry has important applications to theoretical physics such as string theory and it also has many important applications to other branches of mathematics such as number theory and topology. In addition, there are also applications to cryptography through coding using elliptic curves.

In this project, we study various properties of algebraic varieties. Together with Niu and Park, we solve   conjectures of Vermiere, Sidman and Ullery about syzygies and singularities of secant varieties of algebraic curve. More precisely, we show the following. Suppose that the genus of the curve C is g. If the curve is embedded into the projective space by a complete linear system of degree d where d is greater than 2g +2k +p, then the k-th secant variety of C is projective Cohen Macaulay with at worst Du Bois singularities. Furthermore, one controls the p steps minimal resolution of the k-tj secant variety. The techniques of the proof were applied by Park to resolve a conjecture of Ein and Lazarsfeld on asymptotic syzygies of higher dimensional varieties.

 

With Ha and Lazarsfeld, we study the saturation degree of the homogeneous ideal a smooth projective variety. We bounded the saturation degree in terms of the degrees of the equations defining the projective variety. We showed that bound is asymptotically sharp.  This answers an old question of Bombieri. It also completes a project with Bertram and Lazarsfeld on understanding the homogenous of a smooth project variety in terms of the degrees of the homogeneous polynomials cutting out the projective variety. The question of a possible sharp bound for the saturation degree remains

The project has broader impact on training young research mathematicians. During the project, the PI is supervising two students. Fumiaki is currently a Hedrick Assistant Professor at UCLA. He obtained many interesting results on questions about the rationality of Fano varieties, Zhao is a third-year student, He is very active and has already two preprints that appeared on the Arxiv.  The research on the project appeared in well known journals. The PI had given talks about the results at conferences and seminars to communicate the results to other researchers.
